messageBody:
Rick:

You commented on 2/25 that you had trouble reading the "small 'curleys'"
in the Jerome font. I believe this probably stems from two things: 1)
your relative inexperience in reading Quikscript; 2) font size. I have
noticed the smaller fonts do make a few characters harder to read. The
use of a 12 point font plus continued practice will no doubt clear this
up for you.

I believe your statement regarding Jerome looking like "penmanship" is
also a misunderstanding. It is true that Read designed QS so that the
letters naturally formed connections between many of the characters, and
it is true that this speeds up handwriting. But I disagree that this
makes Senior QS unsuitable for "printing." The fact that the roman
alphabet is generally printed without letters touching one another does
not mean this is necessary for reading comprehension. With more
experience in reading, I am confident you will find that the connections
do not hamper comprehension. To my eyes, Senior QS is graceful,
artistic and simpler in appearance than the roman alphabet. The
connections seems very natural in use.

The beginner uses Junior QS because he is unfamiliar with the shapes of
the characters and still learning to form them when he writes. As I
was learning QS some twenty-five years ago, I found that I rapidly
graduated to the Senior form and never looked back after that. Junior
QS seems very simplistic to me and lacks the interest generated by the
unique word-shapes produced by the use of the half-letters and
alternative letters.

Regarding your question about programming a keyboard interface to look
for combinations of letters to avoid using the shift key so much: we
have been discussing remapping the QS alphabet to make it more logical
and easy to learn. This would eliminate the over-dependence on the
"shift" key. Check the recent posts on the Read_Alphabet site about
this.

It would be useful to have a Junior QS font for beginners to aid them in
learning to read QS. And if a person wants to keep using it rather than
going on to Senior QS, that would be okay. No one is forced to use the
half-letters or alternative letters if they don't want to.

I would also suggest that you practice handwriting QS as well as typing
in it. It is very handy for taking personal notes, and it does take
some effort to become proficient in it.

Your comment regarding "chord" typing is interesting. This sounds
something like the machines that court reporters to take testimony down
verbatim. They hit more than one key simultaneously. I don't know how
feasible this would be, but it might be worth looking into if anyone in
the group has any knowledge about how to do this sort of thing.


Paige
